metadata.title: Breast Cancer and Exercise
synonyms: breast cancer in women and exercise
anatomical location body part affected: Breast/mammary tissue (can also involve chest muscle and skin, lymph nodes, or other organs such as bone if metastasis occurs)
description: Breast cancer accounts for 25.1% of all cancers and is the most common form of cancer in women. The incidence of breast cancer is expected to increase to 85 cases per 100,000 women in 2021 (1)

Cancer-related  fatigue (CRF) is defined as a persistent tiredness or exhaustion that can be physical, cognitive, or emotional and that is related to cancer or treatment of cancer. CRF is disproportional to the activity performed and interferes with physical functioning (1)
Sixty to ninety percent of women with breast cancer experience fatigue, and one in four cancer survivors experiences severe fatigue (1)
There is overwhelming evidence to support the benefits of exercise on physical and psychosocial outcomes of women during and after cancer treatment (2)

Women with breast cancer are at a greater risk for experiencing decreased cardiorespiratory fitness, muscular strength, and bone health, which can impact quality of life. Cancer-related  treatments, such as chemotherapy and radiation, as well as obesity and physical inactivity contribute to these negative health outcomes (3)

This Clinical Review  focuses on exercise training for management of breast cancer-related  fatigue and reduced physical function. See Clinical Review ... Cancer-Related  Fatigue and Exercise ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: 5000015209 for additional information on exercise to manage fatigue during and after treatment in other types of cancer

contraindications precautions to test: Individualized screening/assessment for exercise prescription is highly recommended due to the wide variability of tolerance for increased physical activity among patients with breast cancer
Fitness testing may be contraindicated in patients with bone metastasis
Fatigue might prevent completing a functional evaluation in a single appointment

causes of fatigue and functional declin: Cancer and adjuvant treatment (3)–Tumorigenesis/carcinogenesis (6)–Radiation therapy–Chemotherapy–Endocrine therapy
pathogenesis of fatigue and functional: The cause of cancer-related  fatigue is ambiguous.Many factors contribute; they may be due to the cancer itself or itstreatment (4)–Neuropsychological impairment–Muscle metabolism dysregulation–Disruption in circadian rhythm–Elevated mediators of inflammation and stress–Immune activation–Changes in hormones due to effects on the hypothalamic-pituitary  axis–Premature menopause in women or androgen deprivation in men

Patients may experience multiple forms of fatigue, including: (4)–physical fatigue (stress, physical inactivity, idleness)–mental fatigue (reduced attention span, problems with learning and concentration, short-term  memory loss)

Other factors that can contribute to functional decline in patients with breast cancer include–depression and anxiety (4)–emotional distress (4)–disturbed sleep (e.g., anxiety, sleep apnea) (4)–severe dehydration–poor appetite (6)–hypothyroidism (4)–immunosuppression–low-grade  inflammation, as indicated by elevated serum proinflammatory cytokines (4)–metastasis to other sites, including the lungs, bones, lymph nodes, and liver
risk factors: Factors associated with increased risk of breast cancer in women–Personal or family history of breast cancer. The most common risk factor for hereditary breast cancer is an inheritedmutation in the BRCA1  gene or BRCA2  gene because these mutations reduce production of tumor suppressor proteins (6)–Middle age (peak incidence after age 40) (7)–Mammographic increased breast density (8)–Increased endogenous estrogen during lifespan (e.g., early menarche, late menopause, later age at first pregnancy ornulliparity) (6,8)
Obesity and type 2 diabetes (i.e., obesity-related  insulin resistance) (6,7)
Metabolic syndrome (i.e., abdominal obesity, insulin resistance, hyperinsulinemia, and subacute chronic inflammation)(6)
Reproductive factors (age at menarche, age at first birth, age at menopause, use of oral contraceptives, use of hormonereplacement therapy) (7)
Lifestyle factors, such as alcohol consumption(7)

overall contraindications precautions: Patients with bone metastasis require medical clearance for exercise
Obtain clearance, specific precautions, and safety instructions/parameters from patient’s oncologist regarding plans for exercise testing and training
Confirm that the patient does not have any unstable cardiac disease, acute infection, or other acute medical condition that would contraindicate exercise

In patients with postmastectomy complications (e.g., lymphedema, shoulder injury), do not take blood pressure (BP), draw blood, or give injections on the affected upper extremity, as these can worsen the lymphedema/complication. Also, advise patient to avoid constrictive clothing or jewelry that might block lymph drainage (9)
Modify the exercise program as needed to accommodate the patient’s fatigue level, which can be monitored with a visual analog scale (V AS) or brief fatigue inventory (BFI) (4)

For additional information on contraindications/precautions for patients with lymphedema who have had surgical treatment for breast cancer, see Clinical Review ... Lymphedema Following Surgical Treatment for Breast Cancer ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: 5000015499
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Attempt to identify symptoms that may contribute to patient’s functional decline

course of treatment.medical management: What medical treatment has the patient undergone?
surgical management: Surgical management:  Was an oncology surgical procedure such as mastectomy performed? Is the patient receiving ongoing postoperative care? Are there postsurgical guidelines to follow during treatment?
course of treatment.medications: Obtain a complete list of prescribed medications. Are they being taken? Epirubicin or doxorubicin plus cyclophosphamide and docetaxel are commonly used in chemotherapy. Erythropoiesisstimulating  agents (e.g., darbepoetin, epoetin) may reduce functional decline in anemic patients by decreasing the need for blood transfusions and increasing hemoglobin, and methylphenidate (a psychostimulant) may relieve cancerrelated  fatigue(4). Aromatase inhibitors (AIs) such as exemestane, anastrozole, or letrozole may be prescribed to decrease circulating estrogen levels. (8) Study results are mixed regarding the use of modafinil and Lcarnitine  for treating cancer-related  fatigue (4)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Document the laboratory tests and imaging studies that confirmed cancer in this patient
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any home remedies the patient has been using
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other ongoing conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: What specific ADLs are the most difficult or aggravating? How well does the patient cope with fatigue or depression?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a V AS or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if  pain   is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night and factors that interfere with sleep
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document any other symptoms that increase disability in ADLs and/or indicate need for medical consultation. Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder incontinence, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document the need for supplemental oxygen, if applicable Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__/No__ -If Yes, describe  ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Is there a past history of other cancer-related  illness? What was the patient’s regular physical activity status prior to onset of breast cancer?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, other cancers, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders Breast cancer survivors are at a greater risk for developing comorbid conditions such as osteoporosis, sarcopenia, and cardiovascular disease (3)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Is the patient currently on work disability? What does her work require? Did the patient participate in recreational activities or sports prior to this referral?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: What functional limitations does patient have? Does the patient require assistance with ADLs? Document assistive devices that are being used (e.g., cane, crutches, walker, wheelchair)
social and occupational history.living environment: Identify barriers to mobility in the home and whether any modifications regarding stairs, number of floors in home, lack of caregivers are necessary. What support system (family/caregiver) is available?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While the following tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures:  (While the following tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document height, weight, and BMI. Is weight loss indicated?
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess for need, appropriate fit, and appropriate use. Patient may require cane or walker to compensate for severe mobility deficits or severe fatigue. Also consider need for assistive devices to increase safety with bathing, toileting, and transfers
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance; use Berg Balance Scale (BBS) as appropriate. Does impaired balance restrict the patient’s independent use of exercise modalities?
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess vital signs: heart rate (HR), BP, and respiratory rate
Assess functional aerobic endurance with 6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT) at self-paced  speed, with rest pauses as needed

The American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) recommends 150 minutes of moderate-intensity  exercise or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity  aerobic exercise each week, as well as resistance training 2 times a week for large muscle groups, for cancer survivors. Initially, the ACSM recommends three 20-minute  moderate-intensity  walking sessions per week with progression as tolerated (10) -Exercise should be within 50% to 75% of heart rate reserve -Rate of perceived exertion should be between 11 and 14 -These treatment recommendations should be flexible, especially during chemotherapy
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess ability to perform functional tasks that involve using the upper extremities (e.g., reaching, pulling, pushing, holding) and lower extremities (e.g., ascending/descending steps, squatting, kneeling, kicking). Utilize FIM for objective measurement, as indicated
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess walking ability, including synchrony of limb movements and gait speed, as well as posture. Assess safety with Dynamic Gait Index (DGI)Assess joint mobility if indicated by the presence of impaired ROM or movement limitations in functional tasks
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Scan general strength using manual muscle testing (MMT) and strength in functional tasks (e.g., handgrip, pushing, pulling, sit-up,  legpress). Use weight machines for strength testing as indicated for a resistance exercise program. Note if weak or tight chest and shoulder muscles contribute to inefficient movement patterns
observation inspection palpation includi: Measure arm circumference in patients with breast cancer-related  lymphedema (BCRL)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess in sitting, standing, and during gait
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess ROM and flexibility as indicated by movement limitations in functional tasks. If lymphedema is present, assess shoulder ROM and compare affected side to unaffected side if symptoms are unilateral
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Assess severity of fatigue with V AS. Were fatigue symptoms exacerbated by certain activities during the exam?a 22-item  numeric rating scale with 4 subscales that evaluate subjective fatigue, with each item rated from 0 (none) to 10 points (a great deal) (4)evaluates severity of fatigue and impact on daily life for patients with cancera brief 20-question  survey that assesses cancer-related  fatigue distressa questionnaire that assesses fatigue and anemia-related  symptoms in patients with cancer using 41 questions on a five-point  Likert scale  –Short-Form  Health Survey (SF-36)  and the EORTC QLQ-C30 questionnaire may be used to evaluate patient-reported outcomes for general health and QOLa higher score indicates more pain and disability

other: Modify treatment if reported fatigue level becomes moderately severe or higher
Ensure close supervision with instruction throughout exercise and functional training sessions
Electrotherapeutic modalities or functional electrical stimulation should not be used to treat patients with breast cancer unless specifically ordered/approved by the referring physician
Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment regarding the use of modalities
Consult with physician regarding the risks and benefits if resistance exercise is planned for a patient with bone metastasis
Avoid treating patient in a very warm environment, which may exacerbate fatigue symptoms

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Breast cancer/reduced functioning in ADLs and QOL due to persistent fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance; increased risk of cognitive deficits due to physical inactivity; overweight
assessment plan of care.rule out: Physician should investigate all reversible causes of functional decline (e.g., malnutrition, medications, severe dehydration, anemia, sleep apnea, hypothyroidism). Other possible reasons for unexplained persistent fatigue include Epstein-Barr  virus infection, heart failure, depression, and myopathic conditions
prognosis: Moderately strong evidence from RCTs indicates that supervised aerobic and/or resistance training can have positive effects on physical functioning, general fatigue, and HRQoL in breast cancer survivors (4) –Authors of an RCT (N = 91) studied a group of ethnicallydiverse, obese, and physically inactive breast cancer survivors and found that a 16-week  aerobic and resistance training program that aimed to improve metabolic syndrome also demonstrated improvements in HRQoL, depression, fatigue, and physical fitness. These positive effects were maintained after a 3-month  follow-up(3) –Authors of a meta-analysis  involving 2,183 participants found that yoga had a small but significant impact on mitigating fatigue in patients with cancer-related  fatigue (1) –In an RCT involving 337 female participants in Australia, investigators found that exercise was the most beneficial for women who lived in an urban area, who were 55 years old or younger, who had stage II+ breast cancer, or who had at least one comorbidity at time of diagnosis. They also found lower mortality rates in the physical activity group compared to the control group (11) –The results of a meta-analysis  indicated that exercise significantly decreased BMI and improved overall QOL. Authors concluded that exercise should be prescribed to breast cancer survivorsbecause of its multitude of benefits and a lack of adverse effects (12)

Authors of a small study including 24 overweight or obese sedentary postmenopausal women found that a 10-week moderate-intensity exercise intervention increased cardiovascular fitness as measured by VO 2 maximum. However, the intervention did not have a significant impact on sex hormone-binding  globulin, insulin, insulinresistance, or body fat percentage (13)

Authors of a non-randomized  control trial allowed 28 patients with early-stage  breast cancer to choose between an exercise training group and a usual-care  group and measured VO 2 peak before and after anthracycline chemotherapy (14) –In the usual-care  group, a 15% reduction in VO 2 peak was observed, which approximates what would typically be seen after aging 15 years –The decrease in VO 2 peak was significantly different in the exercise group compared to the usual-care group. There was a decrease in VO 2 peak of 0.24 L/min in the usual-care  group and a decrease of 0.1 L/min in the exercise group –Two participants in the exercise group (N = 14) did not demonstrate a decrease in VO 2 peak after undergoing chemotherapy, whereas all participants in the usual-care  group (N = 14) demonstrated decreases in VO 2 peak despite recommendations to maintain physical activity levels

In an RCT 236 patients with stage II breast cancer were divided into three groups: continuous training at moderate intensity, high-intensity  interval training, and control group. Those in the exercise groups participated in 36 sessions of 70 minutes, 3 times a week (15)  –Significant changes in exercise tolerance, muscle strength, and VO 2 max were observed in both exercise groups, but not in the control group –There was a significant reduction in cancer-related  fatigue in the high-intensity  exercise group only –Overall, the study concluded that high-intensity  interval training is safe and effective for women with stage II breast cancer

Aerobic training is safe but not feasible in patients with metastatic (stage IV) breast cancer. Sixty-five  women with stage IV breast cancer were allocated into an exercise group (N = 33) or a stretching group (N = 32). The exercise program consisted of 36 treadmill walking sessions 3 times a week between 55% and 80% VO 2 peak for 12 weeks. Contrary to hypothesis, aerobic training was not associated with an increase in cardiorespiratory fitness or improvement in patient-reported outcomes (16)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Psychiatrist for depression; physician for new or increasing pain; oncologist for unexplained malaise or weight loss; recreational therapist for supervised group exercise; aquatic exercise therapist for pool training; occupational therapist for ADL training; sleep therapist for insomnia; social work for support groups
other considerations: The American Cancer Society (ACS) general guidelines on exercise may help cancer survivors and their families make informed choices on physical activity during the continuum of cancer care. However, in 2018, nearly half (46.7%) of Americans did not meet the recommended amount of moderate to vigorous physical activity (17)

Authors of asmall randomized control trial (N = 17) including female breast cancer survivors compared the effects of moderate-intensity exercise and high-intensity  interval training (HIIT) exercise on cognitive function and found that HIIT may be an effective exercise intervention to improve cognition, aerobic fitness, and cerebrovascular function in female breast cancer survivors (18)
treatment summary: The American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) exercise program guide for cancer survivors recommends vigorous aerobic exercise for 75 minutes per week or 150 minutes of moderate-intensity  exercise per week, and strength exercise at least 2 days per week (10)

Authors of a 2020 meta-analysis  including 29 studies found that resistance exercise does not have a negative effect on breast-cancer-related  lymphedema (BCRL). In fact, resistance exercises increase muscle strength in patients with BCRL (19)

Patients who engaged in exercise (such as brisk walking) at a rate of nine or greater metabolic equivalents (METs) for 2 to 3 hours a week before and after breast cancer diagnosis had a 45% lower risk of death compared to sedentary individuals (20)
In an RCT that included 2,361 breast cancer survivors, researchers found that the most active women had a 53% lower mortality risk compared to the least active women (20)
Engaging in at least 150 minutes of moderate physical activity per week reduced all-cause  mortality by 24% among breast cancer survivors(20)
Patients with very low levels of physical activity (less than or equal to 1.5 METs) demonstrated a 22% increase in breast cancer mortality (20)
In a literature review, authors found that many RCTs and systematic reviews indicated that physical activity has a protective effect against recurrence of and mortality from breast cancer (20)
Weight gain during adulthood or excessive body fat can increase the risk of breast cancer during and after menopause, (21) whereas weight loss may lower the risk of breast cancer (22)

Recommendations from the American Cancer Society (ACS) (17) –Maintain a healthy weight throughout life. Avoid weight gain in adulthood –Be physically active. Adults should aim for 150 to 300 minutes of moderate-intensity  exercise per week or 75 to 150 minutes of vigorous-intensity  physical activity per week. Reaching or exceeding 300 minutes of physical activity is desirable –Children and adolescents should meet or exceed at least 1 hour of moderate or vigorous physical activity per day –Limit sedentary activities, such as screen time, television watching, and lying down –It is recommended to not drink alcohol. Persons who drink alcohol should limit consumption to one drink a day for women and two drinks a day for men  –Follow a healthy diet at all ages, including consuming a variety of fruits, vegetables, and grains while avoiding red and processed meats, sugary drinks, and processed grains

Authors of a systematic review of exercise maintenance in patients with breast cancer found that, of 17 articles reviewed, only 6 demonstrated that significantintervention effects were maintained over time. More research must be done regarding physical activity delivery and mode so that the benefits of physical activity can be maintained in patients with breast cancer (23)

In an observational study (N = 1340 breast cancer survivors post chemotherapy) investigators found that meeting the minimum guidelines for physical activity reduced mortality and recurrence of breast cancer. Meeting minimum guidelines had similar advantages in overall survival compared with meeting and exceeding the guidelines (24)

Authors of an RCT (N = 143) conducted a study of breast cancer patients during adjuvant therapy (25) –The Adapted Physical Activity and Diet (APAD) intervention was evaluated against usual care to determine its effectiveness at decreasing fatigue, anxiety, depression, BMI, and fat mass and enhancing muscular performance and overall QoL –Participants in the APAD intervention group participated in moderate-intensity  exercise 3 times a week and consulted with a dietitian 9 times –Patient-reported  outcomes were measured at baseline, 18 weeks (after chemotherapy), and 26 weeks (end of radiotherapy and intervention), as well as 6 and 12 months post intervention –Significant beneficial effects were observed in all patient-reported  outcomes (depression, anxiety, fatigue, QoL) at 18 and 26 weeks. Positive effects on fatigue and QoL persisted at 12-month  follow-up –At 26 weeks, significant positive effects were observed in BMI, fat mass, and increased muscular endurance, but these did not persist when tested at 6 months or 12 months post intervention –Overall conclusions were that a diet and exercise intervention should begin during early stages of breast cancer diagnosis

van der Leeden et al. explored the importance of comorbidities associated with breast cancer and tailoring an individual exercise program based on these comorbidities. They list possible adaptations to exercise based on comorbidity in their study (26) –Appropriate hygiene or home exercise program for individuals with leukopenia –Avoiding high impact exercises and avoiding point pressure when using equipment for individuals with thrombopenia –Avoid using dumbbells with individuals with loss of sensation in the upper extremities due to risk of dropping them

Thirty-six  studies were included in a systematic review that examined the effects of exercise on QoL in patients with breast cancer (27) –Twenty-two  of 25 studies reported a significant positive effect of aerobic exercise on QoL in patients with breast cancer –Seven of 8 studies reported a significant positive effect of resistance training on QoL in patients with breast cancer. These studies also described the positive effects of combined aerobic and resistance exercise on QoL –Increased adherence to the intervention was associated with improved fatigue, physical well-being,  and QoL –Eight of 12 studies reported that exercising beyond the recommended 150 minutes was associated with a decreased risk of adverse events in breast cancer patients as well as improved QoL –Eight of 11 studies that examined lymphedema found that aerobic and resistance exercise had no negative effects on existing lymphedema and did not cause lymphedema

Home-based  exercise training –Authors of an RCT (N = 82 breast cancer patients) found that adherence to a home-based  exercise intervention was 55 percent. Lower adherence was observed in patients who were obese or who had average or below-average  lower body strength (28) –Authors of an RCT (N = 351 overweight breast cancer survivors) found that a facility-based  program may be more beneficial than an at-home  exercise program for improving lymphedema outcomes (29) –Authors of an RCT in Taiwan (N = 159 women in stages I–III of breast cancer who experience insomnia, pain, fatigue, or depression) found that an at-home  brisk walking program reduced fatigue in women with breast cancer who were undergoing chemotherapy (30)

Progressive resistance training (PRE) –Authors of an RCT studying women undergoing breast cancer surgery with axillary lymph node dissection (N = 158) found no evidence that progressive resistance exercise (PRE) can prevent lymphedema in the first year after breast cancer diagnosis but found that PRE is safe for women with breast cancer (31)  –In an RCT including 158 women researchers found that a 50-week  PRE intervention (supervised for the first 20 weeks and self-administered  for the next 30 weeks) had significant effects on social and emotional functioning and also had a positive impact on pain, sleep, and fatigue (32) –Authors of an RCT of women with breast cancer who underwent axillary lymph node dissection found that PRE provided no benefit in reducing arm pain postoperatively. However, PRE did not increase pain during either short-term  or long-term rehabilitation (33) –.
